Title: More than 5,000 USDA workers fired by Trump ordered back to work for now
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture must temporarily reinstate more than 5,000 probationary employees fired since Feb. 13, according to a ruling by the Merit Systems Protection Board. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: Meet the Syrians behind the music that inspired a revolution
Description: Syrian soccer player Abdel Basset al-Sarout became the poster child for the Syrian revolution with his iconic protest anthems. In death, he has become its saint. But he didn't do it alone. (Image credit: Yahya Nemah for NPR)

Title: Supreme Court upholds lower court order to force USAID to pay contractors
Description: In an order, the justices left in place a lower court order that so far has only required the Trump administration to pay contractors for foreign aid work that has already been completed — roughly $2 billion. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Takeaways from Trump's address to Congress. And, China projects confidence in economy
Description: President Trump delivered a partisan address to a joint session of Congress last night, boasting about his accomplishments from the first six weeks. And, China projects confidence in its economy. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: What went wrong? Israel's spy agency lists failures in preventing Oct. 7 attack
Description: Israel's domestic security agency had Hamas' battle plans for the Oct. 7, 2023 attacks but didn't take them seriously. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu deflected responsibility for the failure. (Image credit: Amir Levy)

Title: God walks with us through the ashes.' A poignant Ash Wednesday after LA wildfires
Description: On Ash Wednesday, Christians hear the words 'Remember that you are dust and to dust you shall return.' Those words ring differently for many whose churches and homes burned in the Los Angeles fires. (Image credit: Jason DeRose)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: A recap of President Trump's address to a joint session of Congress, Trump touts success of some of his immigration policies during address, and China opens its annual session of parliament.

Title: Virginia Sen. Tim Kaine plans to force Republicans to vote on Trump's Canada tariffs
Description: Republicans are 'nervous' about President Trump's tariffs raising prices, says Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia. He plans to force a vote in the Senate on them soon. (Image credit: Nathan Posner)

Title: Central Asian Soviet-era pop music anthology dislays the region's vast diversity
Description: A Central Asian Soviet-era pop music anthology shines a light on the region's ethnic diversity and music that transcends genres from Korean Brass Bands to Uyghur garage rock to Crimean jazz.

Title: As Washington changes course on Ukraine, Taiwan wonders about its own fate
Description: Thousands of miles away from Ukraine, Taiwan is wondering whether it will be the next casualty of the changing moods in Washington, D.C. — and about what they can do to avoid a similar fate.

Title: In Key West, testing shows cruise ships stir up as much sediment as a hurricane
Description: Tests in Key West show sediment stirred up by cruise ships, which can harm marine life, routinely exceed federal standards. Key West has responded by suspending the tests. (Image credit: Handan Khanna)

Title: Federal hiring is nearly frozen. For those who can hire, a new roadblock has emerged
Description: Some federal agencies, like the Department of Veterans Affairs, are largely exempt from President Trump's hiring freeze. But they're hitting a new roadblock in bringing new staff on. (Image credit: Tierney L. Cross)

Title: Some VA hospitals hitting roadblocks in their hiring processes
Description: Some federal agencies, like the Department of Veterans Affairs, are largely exempt from President Trump's hiring freeze. But they're hitting a new roadblock in onboarding staff.

Title: Volunteers in Altadena race to save historic tiles after the LA wildfires
Description: Chimneys are all that are left of many homes that burned in Altadena. Some are adorned with historic tiles, and a group of volunteers are racing to save them before bulldozers come and clear debris.

Title: Trump touts success of some of his immigration policies in address to Congress
Description: President Trump campaigned on border security and strict immigration policy. In his address to a joint session of Congress Tuesday night, he argued he had succeeded in implementing some of his goals.

Title: Elon Musk to send another email to check for non-existent federal workers
Description: Elon Musk says he will send another email to more than 2 million federal workers to see whether they have a pulse. Why is the idea of non-existent employees an animating principle for Musk?

Title: Why a small Colorado town wants to buy its neighboring ski resort
Description: Big conglomerates dominate ownership of America's ski resorts. When a Colorado ski hill went up for sale, a neighboring town launched a bid to buy it to preserve its relaxed culture and affordability.

Title: A look at the human toll of the construction of the Panama Canal
Description: The Panama Canal's impact on the geopolitical stage far outreaches its roughly 51-mile stretch of land and water. This week, we're trying to understand the canal's murky future - from climate change to President Trump's threat to take it for the U.S. - by looking at its turbulent, cataclysmic birth.

Title: China's parliament opens with confidence about the economy despite tariffs, headwinds
Description: China will aim for economic growth of around 5% this year, the same as last year. This comes despite deep domestic challenges and fresh tariffs on Chinese imports to the U.S. (Image credit: Andy Wong)

Title: Cybercrime crew stole then resold hundreds of tickets to Swift shows, prosecutors say
Description: Prosecutors say the majority of the stolen tickets were for Swift's Eras Tour, but the thieves also boosted ones for Adele and Ed Sheeran concerts, NBA games and the U.S. Open Tennis Championships. (Image credit: Lindsey Wasson)

Title: From cheers to protests, here's a look inside the chamber during Trump's speech
Description: Partisan divisions were on display as Republican lawmakers gave Trump frequent standing ovations, while Democrats sat stone faced, held signs and walked out of the chamber in protest. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: Starting with Rep. Al Green, Democrats protest against Trump's speech to Congress
Description: The Texas Democrat stood, shouting, as the president addressed a joint session of Congress. After refusing to retake his seat, Speaker Mike Johnson ordered Rep. Green removed from the chamber. (Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)

Title: Trump administration signals it will let Idaho enforce its restrictive abortion ban
Description: The Justice Department said it would move to dismiss a lawsuit originally filed against Idaho by the Biden administration, according to court papers filed by the state's largest hospital network. (Image credit: Sarah A. Miller)

Title: Mexico and Canada React to U.S. Tariffs; Ukraine Adjusts to Losing U.S. Support
Description: The Trump administration has made good on it's threat to apply 25% tariffs to the two biggest U.S. trading partners, Mexico and Canada. China also had its tariff increased from 10 to 20 percent. Canada and China are hitting back with retaliatory tariffs and Mexico has promised to follow suit. We hear about the reaction and impact. And the Trump administration has announce it is suspending military aid to Ukraine. Our correspondent in Kyiv says Ukraine is figuring out how it can continue despite losing support from the country's single most important ally.

Title: How Trump's foreign policy is reshaping the world order
Description: After the Trump-Zelenskyy blow-up on Friday, European leaders held emergency talks in London to put together a roadmap to peace. Then, on Tuesday, European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen announced a proposal called ReArm Europe. The roughly $840 billion plan would quickly build up defense budgets in Europe. Meanwhile, the U.S. seems to continue to align itself with Russia. President Trump is upending the U.S.-led order that has dominated global politics for the better part of a century. Description: Mexico is accusing the gunmakers of aiding and abetting the gushing pipeline of military-style weapons from the U.S. to Mexican cartels. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: Canada and Mexico hit back as Trump administration launches trade war
Description: The Trump administration slapped 25% tariffs on America's two biggest trading partners, Mexico and Canada. Canada hit back with retaliatory tariffs and Mexico promised to follow suit.

Title: South Carolina plans to carry out a firing squad execution. Is it safe for witnesses?
Description: South Carolina plans to execute its first prisoner by firing squad on March 7 inside the same death chamber it's used for dozens of other executions. Firearms experts say that could be risky. (Image credit: South Carolina Department of Corrections)

Title: Fired federal workers are among the guests invited to Trump's speech to Congress
Description: The Trumps and lawmakers from across the aisle have invited guests to Tuesday's joint address, representing some of the administration's top priorities. Here's a look at some of the names on the list. (Image credit: Mark Wilson)

Title: Trump administration again labels the Houthis a 'foreign terrorist organization'
Description: Trump's first administration similarly designated the Houthis, but the designation was revoked by President Joe Biden's administration over concerns it would affect the delivery of aid to Yemen. (Image credit: Ludovic Marin)

Title: Vance's comments about European peacekeeping plan for Ukraine draw ire abroad
Description: Vice President Vance said the best security guarantee for Ukraine is to sign a mineral deal with the United States. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: U.S. stock market plunge as Trump's tariffs spark fears about a trade war
Description: U.S. stock markets plummeted on Tuesday morning as a new global trade war began. (Image credit: TIMOTHY A. CLARY/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: Canada and China say the fentanyl crisis is only a 'pretext' for Trump's new tariffs
Description: Canadian and Chinese officials say they were already helping reduce fentanyl smuggling. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said fentanyl crossing the northern border is 'near zero.' (Image credit: Katherine KY Cheng)

Title: Chappy the baby seal has died, weeks after being rescued in a Connecticut city
Description: The aquarium helping Chappy — a nod to the New Haven, Conn., neighborhood where he was rescued last month — said he died of gastrointestinal issues and 'was surrounded by love until the very end.'

Title: Europe considers a major defense spending package as Trump signals disengagement
Description: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen proposed an $840 billion plan to build up the bloc's defense, as President Trump pauses military aid to Ukraine. (Image credit: Virginia Mayo)

Title: How to watch Trump's address to Congress. And, Canada retaliates against tariffs
Description: Trump will deliver a speech to Congress tonight, during which he is expected to discuss steps he has taken to further his agenda since taking office. And, Canada and China retaliate against tariffs. (Image credit: Mark Wilson)

Title: Trump is asserting extraordinary power over independent agencies. Is the Fed next?
Description: The rise and potential fall of independent agencies. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: Tariffs have businesses bracing for change in Trump country
Description: President Trump's tariff policy is creating uncertainty for places like Tupelo, Miss. with a manufacturing-dependent economy. It's in a conservative county where Trump got nearly 70% of the vote. (Image credit: Debbie Elliott)

Title: As Trump shrinks other parts of government, immigration task forces grow
Description: The Trump administration is tapping several other agencies to help deport and arrest those without legal status — a novel step that is prompting some pushback. (Image credit: Charly Triballeau)

Title: Celebrated author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: 'I have always longed to be known'
Description: Celebrated Nigerian writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie speaks with NPR's Michel Martin about her new book, 'Dream Count.' (Image credit: Ulf Andersen)

Title: Mexico faces off with U.S. gunmakers at the Supreme Court

Title: Swing state Sen. Elissa Slotkin to deliver rebuttal to Trump's speech to Congress
Description: Michigan's first-term senator, Slotkin — a centrist with deep national security credentials — will deliver the Democrats' rebuttal to President Trump's first speech to a joint session of Congress. (Image credit: Mandel Ngan)

Title: Trump agencies drop dozens of Biden-era cases against crypto, other companies
Description: A Public Citizen report obtained exclusively by NPR shows the new administration has halted or tried to dismiss cases or investigations against at least 89 companies in the last month. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: President Trump pauses Ukraine military aid after disastrous meeting with Zelenskyy
Description: A White House official says the Trump administration Is pausing U.S. aid to Ukraine, just days after a disastrous meeting between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

Description: President Trump pauses Ukraine military aid, President Trump to address to a joint session of Congress Tuesday night, Trump administration imposes tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico.

Description: Mexico is facing off with Smith and Wesson and other gun makers in the US Supreme Court, claiming US-made weapons are fueling drug cartel violence.

Title: Arab and Muslim voters helped deliver Michigan to Trump. They're not all happy so far
Description: Arab and Muslim voters in Michigan, a reliably Democratic voting bloc, backed a Republican for president for the first time in 2024. Now, some are expressing concern about President Trump's rhetoric. (Image credit: Sarah McCammon)

Title: Advocates warn that cuts to HUD will worsen the housing crisis
Description: Advocates warn that deep cuts at the Department of Housing and Urban Development will make the housing crisis worse. Congressional Democrats want more details on what DOGE has done and what it plans.

Title: Trump's threats of economic force against Canada leads to resurgent Liberal Party
Description: Before President Trump was reelected, poll numbers for Canada's Liberal Party were rock bottom. But now they're climbing, due to Trump's goading and economic threats.

Title: China slaps extra tariffs of up to 15% on imports of major U.S. farm exports
Description: China will impose additional tariffs of up to 15% on imports of U.S. farm products, including chicken, pork, and soy. They follow Trump's order to raise tariffs on imports of Chinese products to 20%. (Image credit: Andy Wong)

Title: Severe weather and critical fire risk, ranked 'multi-hazard,' expected nationwide
Description: A spring storm is bringing various weather conditions across the U.S. Some regions are facing snow, possible tornadoes, and critical fire conditions, according to the National Weather Service (NWS). (Image credit: NWS/NOAA)

Description: The news comes just days after a disastrous meeting between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Description: The Trump administration has announced that it's pausing aid to Ukraine. The news comes just days after a disastrous meeting between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

Title: Linda McMahon has been confirmed as Trump's secretary of education
Description: The White House has been clear that it intends to dismantle the U.S. Department of Education, and that it will be McMahon's job to oversee that effort. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: Netanyahu faces conflicting pressures from his right-wing base and Trump
Description: Israel's prime minister is in a bind, caught between President Trump's desire to end the war in Gaza and the demands of his right-wing base that it resume.

Title: Trump wants to get rid of pennies. We go to a coin shop to examine their value
Description: With the news that President Trump wants to get rid of the penny, we stopped by one coin collecting shop to find out their reaction.

Title: A Political Dilemma for Israel's Prime Minister
Description: Our correspondent takes a look at the near future of the the war with Hamas in Gaza through the eyes of Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. He is being pulled in opposite directions politically: President Trump wants the ceasefire in Gaza to continue, while influential right-wing members of Netanyahu's political coalition want fighting to resume. (Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)

Title: NASA's upcoming telescope launch aims to address some existential questions
Description: The new 8.5-foot telescope is set to launch this Tuesday by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory with a clear objective: to explore the origins of the universe. (Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech)

Title: Pope Francis has acute respiratory crises, the Vatican says
Description: Pope Francis experienced more respiratory problems and went on noninvasive ventilation on Monday, the Vatican said, as the head of the Roman Catholic Church battles double pneumonia in the hospital. (Image credit: Mosa'ab Elshamy)

Title: Kroger's longtime CEO resigns abruptly after investigation
Description: The country's largest grocery chain cited an investigation into conduct 'unrelated to the business' but inconsistent with its code of ethics. Rodney McMullen had led Kroger since 2014. (Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon/)

Title: The political power of the pope
Description: Unlike any other religious leader around the world, the leader of the world's one billion Catholics is also the leader of a sovereign nation. And Pope Francis hasn't been shy about using that political power.He's pushed for an end to the wars between Hamas and Israel, and Russia and Ukraine.And he's repeatedly tried to point the world's attention to two ongoing challenges: immigration and climate change. Much of the world has spent the last two weeks focused on Pope Francis' health. And the reason why has as much to do with the fact that he's a powerful geopolitical force as it does with the fact he's a key religious figure. Description: The Oscar documentary win by the movie No Other Land is garnering very different reactions in Israel and the West Bank. (Image credit: Mike Coppola)

Description: Several global leaders pledged support for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's efforts to stop Russia's war. And, heartfelt speeches, a big surprise and history were made at the Oscars. (Image credit: Peter Nicholls)

Title: Seeing Washington change course on Ukraine, Taiwan ponders its own fate
Description: Developments in the Ukraine-U.S. relationship have regularly made headline news in Taiwan lately. Many in Taiwan compare Ukraine's fate to its own, as China continues to threaten an invasion. (Image credit: Ashish Valentine)

Title: Foreign students say the threat of Trump's executive orders is getting real
Description: President Trump warned international students that if they support groups the U.S. deems terrorist organizations, 'we will find you, and we will deport you.' It's left many student activists anxious. (Image credit: John Tlumacki)

Description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy received a warm welcome in London from Britain's prime minster and other European leaders who pledged to work together to stop Russia's war in Ukraine.

Description: There has been a major development in an armed conflict that has raged for decades between Turkey and a Turkish Kurdish group. The group's founder has called for followers to disarm and dissolve.

Description: The country is hosting a major international cricket tournament for the first time in a generation. It's a much-needed bright spot in a nation that's confronted recent economic and political crises. (Image credit: Fadel Senna)

Description: A U.S. District judge sided with Hampton Dellinger, who leads the Office of Special Counsel, in a legal battle over the president's authority to oust the head of the independent agency. (Image credit: Luis M. Alvarez)

Description: The lawsuit says there is no legitimate reason to send migrants to Guantánamo because the U.S. has ample detention facility. (Image credit: Alexander C. Kubitza)

Description: Mardi Gras can make a lot of trash, adding up to millions of pounds each year. Now, some parades in New Orleans are cutting down on their environmental footprint by banning plastic beads.

Description: Up to 3,000 additional troops have been ordered to the U.S.-Mexico border by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the latest in President Trump's efforts to prevent illegal crossings. (Image credit: Herika Martinez)

Description: Leaders from across Europe came quickly to the defense of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, after his televised clash with President Trump and Vice President Vance. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Description: We look at the anticipated impact of of the USAID funding freeze, which helped some of the poorest people around the world. The U.S. Supreme Court is set to weigh in on the matter.

Title: How the fallout of U.S.-Ukraine relations is being perceived in Russia
Description: NPR's Scott Simon speaks with Johns Hopkins professor Sergey Radchenko about what Russia hopes to gain from negotiations with the United States over ending its war in Ukraine.

Title: Alibaba founder Jack Ma returns, 5 years after largely disappearing from public view
Description: NPR's Scott Simon talks to writer Duncan Clark about the return of Jack Ma, founder of online Chinese retailer Alibaba. The tech exec had gone quiet after comments critical of China in 2020.

Title: These National Park workers say a Trump agency fired them illegally. A judge agrees
Description: Eileen and James Kramer were fired from their jobs at Lake Clark National Park in Alaska, even though they both recently received promotions. A judge has found the administration's firings illegal. (Image credit: Eileen and James Kramer)

Title: Trump will address Congress. Why isn't this first speech called a State of the Union?
Description: Trump will give his first speech to Congress next Tuesday since his reelection. It has characteristics of what Americans call a State of the Union address, but it's not officially designated as such. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: Hamas rejects Israel's request to extend phase one of Gaza ceasefire
Description: Hamas says it is not willing to extend the first phase of the Gaza ceasefire, rejecting an Israeli request to delay negotiations on the second phase. (Image credit: Youssef Alzanoun)

Title: In the federal court system, law clerks find little recourse for bullying and abuse
Description: An NPR investigation finds federal judges have enormous influence with few checks on their power. Law clerks and other judicial employees are vulnerable to mistreatment and have few job protections. (Image credit: Isabel Seliger for NPR)

Title: What DOGE cuts could mean for national park visitors

Description: Eggs have become the grocery staple that Americans can't stop talking about, whether its fears of widespread bird flu getting worse or the drastic increase in prices. (Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)

Description: The Vatican says Pope Francis's condition has worsened after a breathing crisis in hospital on Friday - two weeks after he was first admitted to hospital in Rome with bronchitis. (Image credit: Andrew Medichini)

Title: Meeting Trump at White House, Zelenksyy hopes for continued aid in war with Russia

(Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

Title: Iowa has high cancer rates. Trump's cuts to CDC and NIH are already hitting the state
Description: Iowa has the second highest incidence rate of cancer in the country, and it is already feeling Trump's cuts to the workforce and research institutions trying to solve the rural cancer problem. (Image credit: Bri McNulty)

Title: Why the U.S. wants Ukraine's minerals. And AOC speaks with NPR's Steve Inskeep
Description: Trump and Zelenskyy are expected to meet today in Washington, D.C., to sign a preliminary deal. And, AOC tells NPR why she believes the government only works for the wealthy. (Image credit: Evgeniy Maloletka)

Title: Israeli military cites 'fundamental misunderstanding' of Hamas ahead of Oct. 7 attack
Description: The report is the Israeli military's first official account of mistakes that preceded the 2023 attack, which launched Israel's subsequent war against Hamas in Gaza that killed more than 48,000 Palestinians. (Image credit: Leo Correa)

Title: Who's in charge of DOGE? (It's not these women. Or the owl.) Find out in the quiz
Description: Which stores closed and which shows were canceled? Who (or what) was reborn after being hit by a Cybertruck? And is that asteroid going to hit us or what?

Title: In child care centers and on farms, businesses are bracing for more immigration raids
Description: The Trump administration's immigration positions — including mass deportation — have put businesses that employ people without legal status on notice. (Image credit: Etienne Laurent)

Title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tells NPR: 'Everything feels increasingly like a scam'
Description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., about how Democrats are addressing President Trump's agenda.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to meet President Trump Friday in Washington, Tate brothers return to the U.S. from Romania, Supreme Court to hear cases on USAID and executive power.

Title: USAID workers return to HQ to pick up their things
Description: The headquarters of the U.S. Agency for International Development was closed weeks ago. Now, those who worked there are being allowed to return briefly to pick up their things.

Title: USAID workers return to headquarters one last time to pick up their things
Description: The headquarters of the U.S. Agency for International Development was closed weeks ago. On Thursday, those who worked there were allowed to return briefly to pick up their things.

Title: Former USAID head under President George W. Bush discusses the agency's dismantling
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Andrew Natsios, former head of USAID under President George W. Bush, about the dismantling of the international aid agency.

Title: Brothers Andrew and Tristan Tate arrive in the U.S. after leaving Romania
Description: Brothers Andrew and Tristan Tate, who were charged with human trafficking in Romania, have arrived in Florida after their travel restrictions were lifted.

Title: Judge rules mass firing of probationary employees is illegal and should be stopped
Description: The administration fired tens of thousands of federal workers with 'probationary' status, apparently because that made them easier targets. But those workers have rights and protections too and firing them may have been illegal.

Title: Trump's alienation of Europe has China 'delighted,' says former U.S. ambassador
Description: President Trump is threatening to put more tariffs on China. But the U.S. rival is in a better position to ride out American economic retaliation, says former U.S. Ambassador to China Winston Lord. (Image credit: Susan Walsh)

Title: New directive on DOT spending takes community birth and marriage rates into account
Description: A new Trump administration directive for distributing Department of Transportation money prioritizes communities with high birth and marriage rates, and that has transit advocates worried.

Title: Mexico sends drug lord Caro Quintero and 28 others to the U.S.
Description: The unprecedented show of security cooperation comes as top Mexican officials are in Washington trying to head off the Trump administration's threat of imposing 25% tariffs on all Mexican imports. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Boris Spassky, Soviet chess champion who lost to Bobby Fischer, dies at 88
Description: A televised 1972 match between Spassky and Fischer, at the height of the Cold War, became an international sensation and was known as the 'Match of the Century.' (Image credit: Heinz Ducklau)

Title: Trump administration layoffs hit NOAA, agency that forecasts weather, hurricanes
Description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration houses key groups like the National Weather Service. Experts warn the consequences of employee cuts could be drastic. (Image credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images)

Title: A movement is calling for an 'economic blackout' on Friday. Here's what to know
Description: The People's Union USA, a grassroots group, is calling on Americans to join a national boycott by not shopping for 24 hours on Friday. (Image credit: Kamil Krzacynski)

Title: The CFPB drops its lawsuit against Capital One, marking a major reversal
Description: The consumer protection agency also dropped cases against four other companies including Rocket Homes. (Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski/Getty Images)

Title: UN probe reveals the deaths of children in Bangladesh's response to protests last year
Description: A UN investigation into year's deadly student-led protests in Bangladesh found that up to 13% of the victims were children, with most deaths likely caused by security forces.

Title: Egyptians respond to Trump's plan to relocate Palestinians from Gaza
Description: President Donald Trump's ideas for Gaza have sparked concerns in the Middle East. He says Palestinians should all leave and move to Egypt and Jordan.

Title: Palestinian man imprisoned for suicide bombing freed after hostages released from Gaza
Description: A Palestinian man serving 18 life sentences for a pair of bus bombings in 2004 speaks to NPR days after his release.

Title: DOGE work could 'cross extreme ethical and legal lines,' says former employee
Description: On Tuesday, 21 DOGE employees resigned. NPR spoke to one of them who says she felt the new administration was causing 'harm to the American people.' As Elon Musk and the Department of Government Efficiency work to remake the federal government, some of the people tasked with executing his vision have serious concerns about what the changes will do. For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.Email us at considerthis@npr.org. (Image credit: JIM WATSON)

Title: An abrupt departure as USAID workers return to clear their desks at DC headquarters.
Description: The Trump administration has been dismantling the US Agency for International Development, and the headquarters have been closed for weeks. But, on Thursday, workers got to go back to their desks - to clean them out and leave.

Title: USAID workers return to HQ to clear their desks, as Trump dismantles the agency
Description: Workers who served in the U.S. Agency for International Development were allowed a final and brief visit back to their offices to clear out their belongings on Thursday. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Court considers halting Trump's mass firings of federal employees
Description: A federal judge in San Francisco hears arguments in a case challenging the Trump administration's firings of thousands of probationary employees — those in their first year or so on the job. (Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin/AP)

Title: ICE will reopen a major detention center in New Jersey as it eyes a broader expansion
Description: The Trump administration is expanding its immigration detention capacity, reopening a 1,000-bed detention center in New Jersey and adding beds at other privately owned facilities around the country. (Image credit: ICE via)

Title: Martin Marty, leading scholar of American religion, dies at 97
Description: Martin Marty, one of the foremost interpreters of religion in American public life, died on Tuesday. He was 97 years old. (Image credit: Photo courtesy University of Chicago.)

Title: 2 years after Greece's deadliest train crash, victims and families await answers
Description: On Feb. 28, 2023, a passenger train and freight train collided, leaving 57 dead. New evidence suggests many may not have been killed by the crash itself, but by a fire that followed. (Image credit: SAKIS MITROLIDIS)

Title: Trump says he doesn't see need for U.S. security guarantees to end Ukraine-Russia war
Description: In a meeting with the British Prime Minister, Trump said reaching a peace deal would be the 'difficult part.' He said security would be made easier by a U.S. deal with Ukraine on critical minerals. (Image credit: Carl Court)

Title: Andrew Tate, facing rape and trafficking charges in Romania, is back in the U.S.
Description: The Tate brothers have been allowed to leave Romania, where they were charged with human trafficking, rape and forming a criminal group to sexually exploit women. They arrived in Florida on Thursday. (Image credit: Marta Lavandier)

Title: The U.S. resumes hundreds of millions in security aid to Taiwan, annoying China
Description: The U.S. has unfrozen millions in security assistance for Taiwan, with an eye toward China. (Image credit: I-Hwa Cheng)

Title: Pentagon directs removal of trans service members from military
Description: Service members and recruits who are diagnosed with or treated for gender dysphoria are to be separated from the U.S. military in accordance with an executive order issued a month ago by President Trump. (Image credit: Jim Watson)

Title: Syrian Jews return to Damascus for the first time in decades, hoping to build bridges
Description: Thousands of Jews left Syria in 1992, when they were allowed to emigrate. The visit by a small delegation of U.S.-based Syrian Jewish religious figures last week was their first time back since then. (Image credit: Ayman Oghanna for NPR)

Title: Republican Sen. Josh Hawley discusses his mission to hold big tech accountable
Description: Republican Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri talks about his mission to hold tech companies accountable even as they try to align themselves with President Donald Trump.

Title: Trump administration cuts most USAID programs. And, the ethics of leaving your job
Description: Nearly all USAID programs have been eliminated. One official says it's a 'global health massacre.' And, a federal judge will hear arguments over the decision to fire thousands of probationary workers. (Image credit: Jam Sta Rosa)

Title: Thailand deports dozens of Uyghurs to China, activists say
Description: The detainees were part of a group of some 300 Uyghurs who fled China and were arrested in Thailand in 2014. Thailand deported more than 100 of them to China in 2015, drawing condemnation. (Image credit: Haruka Nuga)

Title: Language as protagonist in Cristina Rivera Garza's newly translated novel
Description: Pulitzer winner Cristina Rivera Garza offers new perspective on gender violence through a murder mystery and poetry.

Title: A rare 'parade' of all 7 planets will move across the night sky this week
Description: This phenomenon known as a 'planet parade,' will feature Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune all present at the same time along a line in the night sky on Friday, NASA says. (Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech)

Title: How Trump's crackdown plays into misperceptions about immigrants and crime
Description: The White House portrays its immigration crackdown as a success. Critics say the administration is trying to look tough for the cameras, and worry about the 'tail wagging the dog.'

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Trump administration ending thousands of foreign assistance grants and awards, Venezuelan men allege mistreatment at Guantánamo, judge to hear arguments on dismissal of probationary federal employees.

Title: What Greenlanders say about Trump's plans for the territory
Description: President Trump says he wants to take over Greenland. Some of the Danish territory's roughly 57,000 residents share how they feel about the island's current ties with the U.S. and Denmark.

Title: Federal judge to hear arguments on dismissal on probationary federal employees
Description: The Trump administration is facing legal challenges as it moves to shrink the federal workforce. A judge will hear arguments Thursday on whether dismissal of probationary employees should be halted.

Title: 4 thoughts on Trump's aggression toward Europe from EU's foreign policy chief
Description: President Trump is threatening the European Union with steep tariffs. The EU's foreign policy chief said leaders there wonder what they've done to warrant such treatment. (Image credit: Virginia Mayo)

Title: European Union foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas discusses shifting U.S. alliances
Description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with European Union foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas {Ky-uh KAL-uss} about how the E.U. views shifting U.S. alliances.

Title: Republican Sen. Josh Hawley discusses his mission to hold big tech accountable
Description: Republican Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri talks about his mission to hold tech companies accountable even as they try to align themselves with President Donald Trump.

Title: Hamas returns bodies of four hostages and Israel releases hundreds of Palestinians
Description: Both sides agreed there would be no Hamas ceremonies for the hostage bodies and in exchange Israel would release the Palestinian detainees and prisoners whose freedom had been held up since Saturday. (Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)

Title: Taiwan condemns China for conducting shooting drills off its coast
Description: Taiwan said in a 24-hour period it detected 45 aircraft, 14 navy vessels and one ship from the Chinese military operating around Taiwan, of which 34 had crossed into its waters and airspace. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Trump cuts financial lifeline for Venezuela by ending permit to export oil to U.S.
Description: Trump's accused the government of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro of not meeting democratic conditions for last year's July presidential election as well as of not moving fast enough to transport back immigrants set for deportation. (Image credit: Matias Delacroix)

Title: Over 7,000 from scam centers in Myanmar are awaiting repatriation after crackdown
Description: Trapped in virtual slavery, many are lured to work in scam centers where they exploit people around the world through false romances, bogus investment pitches and illegal gambling schemes. (Image credit: Thanaphon Wuttison)

Title: Oscar-nominated Brazilian film sparks debate about country's past
Description: Brazilians are flocking to the theaters to see its Oscar-nominated film I Am Still Here. It tells the story of a family devastated by the military dictatorship that ruled from 1964. There has never been a truth commission to investigate abuses or prosecutions of those accused of wrongdoing during a two-decade-long rule. Advocates hope the film might lead to a better understanding of that dark past. (Image credit: Amanda Edwards)

Title: Is there a deal to end Russia's war with Ukraine?
Description: On Friday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is scheduled to meet President Donald Trump at the White House.On the agenda — a deal for Ukraine to share its rich natural resources. The Trump administration wants hundreds of billions of dollars of rare earth metals and other critical minerals. Details are thin on what exactly Ukraine would get in exchange. The meeting comes as the world marks three years since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and as Trump promises to bring an end to the war.But bringing an end to the war may not be so simple argues Alexander Vindman.The Uk...

Title: 14-year-old 'Human Calculator' sets mental math record
Description: There's a new Guinness World Record holder for how fast someone can do math. Aaryan Shukla -- who has been dubbed 'the human calculator' can solve complex problems in his head in seconds.

Title: Critics fear that President Trump's immigration crackdown plays into misperceptions
Description: The White House is touting its crackdown on illegal immigration. But critics worry it's putting optics ahead of substance, and reinforcing widely held misperceptions about immigrants and crime.

Title: 5 minerals in Ukraine that may be part of a deal with the U.S.
Description: President Trump says Ukraine is ready to sign a deal with the U.S. to share its mineral wealth. We look at five minerals and metals that could be covered by the deal. (Image credit: Sunday Alamba/AP)

Title: The search for the missing Malaysian Airlines Flight MH370 has resumed once again
Description: After 11 years of the plane's untraceable disappearance, authorities have announced that the search is back on. (Image credit: Rahman Roslan/Getty Images)

Title: A blackout left most of Chile in darkness for 7 hours
Description: For over seven straight hours in Chile, the electricity went out and plunged the country into chaos.

Title: How federal job cuts are playing out in Western states
Description: Red states with lots of federally owned land have long called agencies managing them 'bloated.' Now, agency job cuts are affecting local economies.

Title: As Elon Musk continues sweeping cuts to the US government: 'People are really scared'
Description: DOGE has eliminated thousands of federal jobs and canceled more than 1,000 contracts. Harvard professor Elizabeth Linos warns, 'We're seeing harms that are not going to be easily undone.'

Title: Trump suspends the head of 'The Nation's Report Card'
Description: Peggy Carr, a federal official who leads one of the country's most extensive student testing programs, known as The Nation's Report Card, was placed on administrative leave. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer is set to visit the White House. Here's what to know
Description: In his visit on Thursday, the prime minister will try to leverage the U.K.'s so-called 'special relationship' with U.S. and act as a bridge between the Trump administration and U.S. allies in Europe. (Image credit: Leon Neal)

Title: The U.S. and Ukraine are close to agreeing on a framework deal for critical minerals
Description: President Trump says Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will come to the U.S. Friday to sign a deal. (Image credit: Evgeniy Maloletka)

Title: How federal layoffs are impacting national parks, from reduced hours to safety fears
Description: Some 1,000 NPS employees were fired, and hiring for seasonal positions was delayed. Here's what to know about the impacts already being felt at parks, and what it could mean for the busy season. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: Trump's social media video garners pushback from Arabs and Muslims in U.S. and Gaza
Description: In a seemingly AI-generated video that the president posted on social media, images of destruction due to the war in Gaza are transformed into a glitzy resort called 'TRUMP GAZA.' (Image credit: Screenshots via Instagram. Annotation by NPR)

Title: The House passed a budget resolution. What's next? And, a tactic to decrease bird flu
Description: House Republicans rallied together yesterday to pass multitrillion-dollar plan to address defense, immigration and more. And, why farmers don't like the idea of vaccinating poultry for bird flu. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Israelis hold a mass funeral for Shiri Bibas and her two sons killed in Gaza
Description: Crowds gathered in Israel for the funeral procession of the Bibas family, a mother and two young sons killed while being held hostage in Gaza. The story of their killing has enraged Israelis, and Israeli government representatives were not invited to the funeral. (Image credit: Ariel Schalit)

Title: For Women's History Month, NPR wants to know who has made an impact in your life
Description: Is there a woman who has impacted your life in a profound way? NPR wants to hear your story. (Image credit: Kevin Winter)

Title: Tablets for tots? Survey says kids watch videos on their own devices by age 2
Description: A.I. is the other big change in the media landscape for kids and parents, the report from Common Sense Media finds. (Image credit: Riccardo Milani)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: House Republicans pass budget framework advancing Trump agenda, the conflicting messaging over who's in charge of some government decision-making, egg farmers say they're losing the bird flu battle.

Title: How Musk's efforts to reduce the federal workforce compare to efforts in the 1990s
Description: NPR speaks with Brookings' Elaine Kamarck about her 1990s effort to shrink the federal workforce and how it compares to Elon Musk's approach today. (Image credit: AP)

Title: How Musk's efforts to reduce the federal workforce compare to efforts in the 1990s
Description: NPR speaks with the Brookings Institution's Elaine Kamarck about her effort to reduce the size of the federal workforce during the 1990s and how it contrasts to Elon Musk's efforts today.

Title: Pope Francis is still in critical condition, but he had another 'restful night'
Description: Francis, 88, has been in critical condition for several days and he has remained absent from several regular appearances. The church has encouraged worshippers around the world to pray for his health. (Image credit: Andrew Medichini)

Title: Former deputy national security adviser in first Trump term defends shift on Europe
Description: Steve Inskeep speaks with Victoria Coates, former deputy national security adviser during the first Trump administration, about America's shifting international alliances.

Title: Israel and Hamas agree on a new exchange, leaving a fragile ceasefire intact
Description: The bodies of four Israeli hostages are to be returned late Wednesday and more than 600 Palestinian prisoners and detainees freed during the last week of the current Gaza ceasefire deal. (Image credit: Alexi J. Rosenfeld)

Title: A sweeping power blackout leaves most of Chile in darkness
Description: Internet and mobile phone services blinkered offline. People complained of water shortages as pumps stopped working. Emergency generators helped hospitals and government offices continue operating. (Image credit: Matias Basualdo)

Title: Federal board orders government to reinstate six workers fired by Trump
Description: The Merit Systems Protection Board, the quasi-judicial agency that hears appeals in federal employee labor disputes, has ordered a stay in the firing of six probationary employees. (Image credit: Krisanapong Detraphiphat)

Title: Southwest 737 and small business jet have 'near collision' at Chicago Midway Airport
Description: Federal authorities are investigating a near-collision at Chicago's Midway airport between a Southwest 737 and a small business jet. The 737 was landing when the business jet entered the runway. (Image credit: StreamTime Live)

Title: Judge tells Trump administration it has less than 2 days to resume USAID funding
Description: U.S. District Judge Amir H. Ali said officials have provided no evidence of compliance with repeated orders to unfreeze the money. (Image credit: Jam Sta Rosa/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: Diana Taurasi, 6-time Olympic gold medalist and the WNBA's top scorer, will retire
Description: Taurasi leaves her basketball career as the most decorated woman to ever play, with three WNBA titles, three NCAA titles and six Olympic gold medals to her name. (Image credit: Christian Petersen)

Title: Clearing Syria of unexploded munitions from the civil war
Description: During a brutal 14-year civil war, Syria's ousted regime dropped hundreds of thousands of bombs and munitions on its own civilians. Now Syria faces the challenge of clearing the unexploded munitions.

Title: Huntsville, Ala., hopes President Trump delivers on Space Command
Description: The city of Huntsville, Alabama has a lot to gain and possibly lose under the Trump administration. Known as the Rocket City, half of its GDP comes from the federal government.

Title: More than 40,000 Palestinians have been displaced in the West Bank in the last month
Description: More than 40,000 Palestinians have been displaced in the past month in the West Bank due to the Israel's prolonged military operation there. It's the largest displacement in the West Bank in decades.

Title: As Greenland prepares for tourism increase, a moment of stillness among the icebergs
Description: As Greenland resists U.S. acquisition threats, it's also welcoming an increase in tourism. Industry leaders and residents are preparing to make the island more accessible to visitors.

Title: Venezuelan men allege mistreatment while in detention in Guantánamo Bay
Description: The men told NPR they were kept in the dark about why they were in Guantánamo Bay, and were denied access to an attorney or a phone call with loved ones. (Image credit: PEDRO MATTEY)

Title: While sanctions still cripple a shattered Syria, one Jewish leader returns from exile
Description: During the Assad regimes, Western nations placed crippling economic sanctions on the country. Some have been lifted, but most are still in place, so how does a country shattered by civil war rebuild? And we follow the return to Damascus of one US Syrian Jewish leader, after decades in exile.

Title: The view from Greenland: 'We don't want to be Americans'
Description: President Trump's calls for the U.S. to take over Greenland have sparked alarm and outrage.Denmark, which is responsible for Greenland's security, recently announced that it would further boost its defense spending.And a recent poll found 85 percent of Greenlanders are opposed to being part of the United States.Parliamentary candidate Naaja Nathanielsen is one of them.It isn't clear whether Trump's ambitions for Greenland will take.
