Title: Tell us your story about car insurance premiums
Description: Car insurance premiums have been soaring. NPR wants to hear about what you've experienced in your premium costs, and why. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: A snowshoe trek in the Adirondack Mountains on a classic winter day
Description: Snowshoeing in the Adirondacks on a winter day with chickadees for company (Image credit: Brian Mann)

Title: Rollback of diversity efforts leaves teachers wondering about effects on Black History Month
Description: The Education Department's efforts to keep racial diversity out of schools has left educators wondering how and when to teach students about Black history, especially during Black History Month. (Image credit: Kassidy Arena)

Title: Fabric giant Joann is going out of business and closing all of its 800 stores
Description: The crafts retailer formerly known as Jo-Ann Fabrics had been struggling financially for several years following a DIY-driven uptick in sales during the early days of the pandemic. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: The odds of a 'city-killer' asteroid hitting Earth have fallen to zero
Description: After weeks at the top of the Sentry list at the Center for Near-Earth Object Studies, the asteroid 2024 YR4 is no longer considered a threat to Earth. (Image credit: AP)

Title: How is Pope Francis doing? The Vatican says he rested well and met church officials
Description: Pope Francis 'rested well throughout the night' in the hospital, the Vatican says, and even met with Vatican officials to sign several documents linked to sainthood designations on Monday. (Image credit: Luciano Gonzalez)

Title: Supreme Court throws out death sentence, murder conviction of Okla. death row inmate
Description: The court reversed the state court's judgement and sent the case back for a new trial. (Image credit: Larry French)

Title: From deportations to health care, state lawmakers are key for much of Trump's domestic agenda
Description: Federal power only goes so far. State governors and legislatures have wide authority over local law enforcement, schools, health and how cities and counties handle immigration. (Image credit: Pool)

Title: Joy Reid fired from MSNBC amid network shakeup
Description: Reid is a longtime political commentator who has been vocal on progressive issues and sharply critical of President Trump. (Image credit: Arturo Holmes)

Title: Who is Alice Marie Johnson, Trump's newly appointed 'pardon czar'?
Description: Johnson, now 69, was facing life in prison without the possibility of parole for being a first-time nonviolent drug offender. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: Trump's funding freeze threatens key river. And, U.S. votes against Ukraine peace plan
Description: Trump's funding freezes could threaten the Colorado River. Some money was intended to keep the shrinking river flowing. And, the U.S. voted against a U.N. peace resolution for Ukraine. (Image credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Title: 5 signs that a U.S.-Europe split is widening
Description: As the Trump administration ramps up its rhetoric against Ukraine and NATO, European countries are taking note — with increasing alarm. (Image credit: Tobias Schwarz)

Title: Top Ukrainian official says Kyiv will refuse any 'bad' peace deal
Description: Ihor Brusylo, deputy head of Ukraine's President's Office, tells NPR Trump is a 'peacemaker and dealmaker,' while expressing hope the U.S. continues to provide aid to Ukraine. (Image credit: Richard Drew)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: U.S. opposes a resolution demanding that Russia withdraw from Ukraine, Trump funding freeze includes payments to keep the Colorado River flowing, massive child sex abuse trial begins in France.

Title: Syrian Jews return to Damascus hoping to rebuild a community
Description: The overthrow of the Assad regime in Syria paved the way for a historic visit, with Syrian Jews returning from the U.S. to Damascus for the first time in three decades, hoping to rebuild community.

Title: President of the Iowa Farmers Union discusses anticipated Agriculture Department cuts
Description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Aaron Lehman, a fifth-generation farmer who is president of the Iowa Farmers Union, about anticipated cuts to Department of Agriculture programs.

Title: Former U.S. ambassador to Hungary discusses democratic decay under PM Orbán
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with David Pressman, former U.S. ambassador to Hungary, about that country's democratic decay under Prime Minister Viktor Orbán.

Title: U.S. votes against U.N. resolution urging Russia's withdrawal from Ukraine
Description: The U.N. General Assembly adopted a resolution Monday condemning Russian aggression and calling for the immediate withdrawal of Russian forces from Ukraine. The U.S. joined Russia in opposing it.

Title: Foreign policy expert Stephen Walt discusses America's shifting alliances
Description: As the Trump administration aligns itself more closely with Russia, foreign policy expert Stephen Walt at Harvard University discusses the repercussions of America's shifting alliances.

Title: French surgeon on trial accused of raping or abusing 299 people, mostly children
Description: A former surgeon in France, now 74, is on trial for the alleged rape or sexual abuse of 299 victims, most of them children. Investigators say the violence spanned more than three decades.

Title: Pakistan's cricket fans rejoice as country hosts first major tournament in years
Description: Pakistanis have found reason to celebrate as the country hosts a major international cricket tournament for the first time in years.

Title: Top Ukrainian official says Kyiv will refuse any 'bad' peace deal
Description: Ihor Brusylo {EE-hor BROO-see-low}, deputy head of the Office of the President of Ukraine, speaks with NPR's Steve Inskeep about the latest talks of a deal with Russia, and the U.S.'s shifting position on backing Kyiv.

Title: Retired FBI agent gives initial impressions of Kash Patel and Dan Bongino
Description: The new top two leaders at the FBI are Trump loyalists with no prior experience at the bureau. NPR asks retired FBI special agent Thomas J. Baker for his impressions of Kash Patel and Dan Bongino.

Title: What to expect at the FBI under the leadership of Kash Patel and Dan Bongino
Description: The new top two leaders at the FBI are Trump loyalists with no prior experience at the bureau. NPR's Leila Fadel asks retired FBI special agent Thomas J. Baker for his impressions of both men.

Title: Trump funding freeze includes payments to keep the Colorado River flowing
Description: President Biden promised billions in funds to farmers and others to not take water from the Colorado River. President Trump is halting some of those funds, leaving questions about the river's future. (Image credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Title: Clint Hill, the Secret Service agent who tried to shield the Kennedys, dies at 93
Description: Hill received Secret Service awards and was promoted for his actions that day, but for decades blamed himself for Kennedy's death, saying he would gladly have given his life to save the president. (Image credit: James W. Ike Altgens)

Title: Germany's historic election. And the impact of 3 years of war in Ukraine
Description: The man poised to become Germany's new Chancellor says the US administration doesn't care about the fate of Europe. And, on the third anniversary of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine what has been the impact of the largest conflict in Europe since the second world war? (Image credit: Marcus Brandt)

Title: The Panama Canal needs more water. The solution is a dam that could displace thousands
Description: More than 2,000 people could be displaced by the construction of the Río Indio dam. The Panama Canal Authority says the dam solves a long-term water shortage problem. (Image credit: Tomas Ayuso for NPR)

Title: Layoffs at federal housing agency HUD would worsen homelessness, employees say
Description: The Trump administration wants massive staff cuts at the federal housing agency. Employees and others say they could end up making record-high homelessness even worse.

Title: The changes that lie ahead for Germany after Sunday's election
Description: German voters gave the far-right AfD party second place in elections, which will make the Christian Democrat Party's Friedrich Merz the next chancellor.

Title: Prosecutor Fani Willis is fighting to keep her case against President Trump alive
Description: Donald Trump and Atlanta prosecutor Fani Willis began their second terms in office a few weeks apart. Here's a look at how their fates have diverged over the last year.

Title: World leaders are in Ukraine's capital to mark 3 years since Russia launched its war
Description: As the U.S. turns away from Ukraine, more than a dozen leaders gather in Kyiv as Ukrainians mark three years since Russia's invasion and ongoing war.

Title: Western sanctions are holding Syria back from rebuilding, locals say
Description: Western countries have imposed layers of crippling sanctions on Syria for decades. Syrians say the sanctions are impeding any hope of rebuilding a country shattered by civil war.

Title: Miami Beach is again cracking down to keep spring breakers away
Description: Miami Beach is again cracking down on spring breakers this year after major restrictions kept large crowds away in 2024.

Title: Trump and Macron meet in Washington as Europe pleads for continued help for Ukraine
Description: In a conversation between President Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron in the Oval Office Monday, the two leaders seemed friendly even when they appeared far apart on the war in Ukraine. (Image credit: Ludovic Marin)

Title: U.S. votes against a U.N. resolution urging Russia's withdrawal from Ukraine
Description: The European-backed resolution that was approved demands Russia immediately withdraw its forces. The Trump administration had offered a competing resolution that did not mention Russian aggression. (Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson/AP)

Title: DHS memo lays out plans to detain migrants at Fort Bliss and other U.S. bases
Description: The Trump administration is developing plans to build immigration detention facilities on bases nationwide, a step that could significantly expand the military's role in immigration enforcement. (Image credit: U.S. Army Sgt. 1st Class Nicholas J. De La Pena)

Title: Mikaela Shiffrin seals legacy as one of skiing's greatest with historic 100 World Cup wins
Description: After a bruising crash last November, Mikaela Shiffrin dominated the slopes on Sunday and made skiing history once again. (Image credit: Stefano Guidi)

Title: Who is Dan Bongino? What to know about Trump's pick for FBI deputy director
Description: Dan Bongino has been chosen as the FBI's second-in-command, a job that doesn't need Senate confirmation. Here's what to know about the Secret Service agent-turned-conservative media personality. (Image credit: Calla Kessler)

Title: Pope rests in his 10th day of hospitalization but remains in critical condition
Description: Francis, 88, had remained in critical condition throughout the weekend after severe breathing difficulties were reported. (Image credit: ALBERTO PIZZOLI)

Title: Macron, Trump to discuss Ukraine peace plan. And, Greenpeace faces $300 million lawsuit
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to present the European peace plan for Ukraine to President Trump today. And, Greenpeace faces a lawsuit that could shut it down. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: A 10-year-old's story of family immigration that spans three continents
Description: A California fourth-grader's interview with her grandfather, who was forced out of Uganda before moving to the U.S., is one of our outstanding podcasts. (Image credit: Janet Woojeong Lee)

Title: Republicans' love/hate relationship with the Education Department
Description: President Trump has made clear he wants to close the U.S. Department of Education, but Republicans seem torn on just how far to go. (Image credit: Jon Cherry)

Title: 3 years on, here's what to keep an eye on in the Ukraine war — and efforts to end it
Description: Thousands of civilians have been killed since Russia launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022. Amid a stark shift in U.S. policy, Ukrainians want the war to end — but not on Russia's terms. (Image credit: Anton Shtuka for NPR)

Title: Federal workers feel betrayed and alone in Trump administration's chaotic purge
Description: Mike Macans is one of an unknown number of Small Business Administration employees who were fired, unfired and fired again as part of the Trump administration's deep cuts to the federal workforce. (Image credit: Ash Adams for NPR)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron to meet President Trump in D.C., center-right opposition party wins in Germany's election, Greenpeace faces $300 million lawsuit after Dakota Access Pipeline protests.

Title: Israel delays Palestinian prisoner release, while sending tanks to occupied West Bank
Description: Israel delayed a Palestinian prisoner release, accusing Hamas of 'humiliating' hostages, while also sending tanks into the occupied West Bank for the first time in decades.

Title: Trial starts for man charged with killing 7 during July Fourth parade near Chicago
Description: Trial gets underway for a man charged with killing 7 people during a 2022 July 4th parade near Chicago. His father served time for helping his then-teenage son secure a gun license, despite red flags.

Title: NPR listeners tell us about the local Black heroes making a difference in their lives
Description: Black History Month often invokes the past, but Black history is made every day. We asked NPR listeners to tell us about local Black figures making a difference in their communities.

Title: French President Emmanuel Macron to meet President Trump in Washington
Description: French President Macron will meet Trump Monday and is expected to present the European plan for peace in Ukraine. Trump abruptly reversed alliances last week, blaming Ukraine for causing the war.

Title: What are the prospects for peace in Ukraine 3 years after Russia launched its war?
Description: Three years after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, what has been the impact of the largest conflict in Europe since World War II? How does the U.S. pivot toward Russia affect peace prospects?

Title: Email asking federal workers to detail accomplishments stokes confusion and anger
Description: Federal employees were told they have until the end of Monday to detail what they accomplished last week or face firing. Some bosses said to hold on before replying to the email, stoking confusion.

Title: Historian Anne Applebaum breaks down what Trump's alignment with Russia means
Description: Historian Anne Applebaum says America's shifting alliances with anti-democratic nations, particularly Russia, raise questions about the state of world order and long-standing alliances. (Image credit: Susan Walsh)

Title: Anne Applebaum discusses America's shifting alliances toward anti-democratic nations
Description: Anne Applebaum, a writer with 'The Atlantic,' talks with NPR's Leila Fadel to unpack the implications of America's shifting alliances with anti-democratic nations, particularly Russia.

Title: Trump names conservative media personality Dan Bongino as FBI deputy director
Description: The selection places two staunch Trump allies atop the nation's premier federal law enforcement agency at a time when Democrats are concerned that the president could seek to target his adversaries. (Image credit: Susan Walsh/AP)

Title: A French surgeon is on trial accused of raping or abusing 299 people, mostly children
Description: The trial comes as French activists are pushing to lift taboos that surround sexual abuse. The most prominent case was that of Gisèle Pélicot, who was raped by her now ex-husband and dozens of others. (Image credit: Aurelien Morissard)

Title: Center-right opposition wins German election, with the far right coming in 2nd
Description: Conservative opposition leader Friedrich Merz won a lackluster victory in a national election Sunday, while the far-right Alternative for Germany doubled its support, projections showed. (Image credit: Markus Schreiber)

Title: Trump's tariffs and rhetoric strain historic Windsor-Detroit friendship
Description: President Donald Trump's tariffs and comments about turning Canada into the 51st state have tested U.S. relations with the country. One example is the deterioration of longstanding bonds between Detroit, Michigan and its neighbor across the river, Windsor, Ontario. NPR's Don Gonyea is a Detroit native and current resident of the city. He's had a front row view to changing attitudes between the two populations who have long enjoyed a very friendly, symbiotic relationship.For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.Email us at considerthis@npr.org. (Image credit: Paul Sancya)

Title: How one community in Chile is blessed and cursed with lithium
Description: Chile is the world's second-largest lithium producer. It has been a welcome boon to the economy, but local community members consider it a disaster. (Image credit: Cristóbal Olivares for NPR)

Title: LA's wildfire cleanup efforts struggle to meet Trump's deadline amid FEMA setbacks
Description: The Palisades and Eaton wildfires left a vast amount of toxic debris. NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Tony Briscoe, environmental reporter at The Los Angeles Times, about where the cleanup stands.

Title: Huge crowds gather in Lebanon for funeral of slain Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah
Description: Hezbollah held a long-delayed funeral for former leader Hassan Nasrallah, who was assassinated in September in an Israeli airstrike. (Image credit: Hassan Ammar)

Title: Hezbollah to hold funeral for Hassan Nasrallah, assassinated by Israel in September
Description: Hezbollah on Sunday holds a long-delayed funeral for leader Hassan Nasrallah, killed in an Israeli airstrike in Beirut in November. The event is expected to be akin to a state funeral, marking the end of an era for the Iran-backed group.

Title: Why Ukrainians are skeptical of a ceasefire deal even after 3 years of war
Description: It has been three years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine. NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Ukrainian journalist Nataliya Gumenyuk about how Ukrainians feel about the ceasefire discussions that don't include them.

Title: A police officer on duty on January 6, 2021, reflects on the attackers' pardons
Description: Police officer Daniel Hodges was attacked on Jan. 6, 2021, at the Capitol. He was also on duty during President Trump's inauguration last month. He reflects on the pardons attackers received.

Title: Israel delays Palestinian prisoner release; moves tanks into West Bank
Description: Israel is delaying the release of Palestinian detainees and prisoners, disrupting the Gaza ceasefire deal, and its military is intensifying an offensive in the occupied West Bank (Image credit: Zain Jaafar)

Title: Pope Francis rested during a peaceful night following respiratory crisis
Description: Pope Francis, in critical condition with a complicated lung infection, rested well during a peaceful night following a respiratory crisis and blood transfusions, the Vatican said Sunday. (Image credit: Gregorio Borgia)

Title: Who is Trump's pick for chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, Dan Caine?
Description: Caine is a career fighter jet pilot who defended Washington, D.C., during the 9/11 attacks and been adored by Trump since they met in Iraq during Trump's first term. (Image credit: U.S. Air Force)

Title: President Trump fires 6 top-level military officers. A retired rear admiral reacts
Muslims in Michigan react to the first few weeks of the Trump administration
Description: In November's election, Trump picked up significant support among Arab and Muslim voters in the key swing state of Michigan.

Title: Friedrich Merz may become the next German chancellor. But who is he?
Description: Friedrich Merz of the Christian Democratic Union is expected to be Germany's next chancellor.

Title: Pope Francis is in critical condition, the Vatican says
Description: The 88-year-old Francis has been hospitalized for a week with a complex lung infection. (Image credit: Gregorio Borgia)

Title: A Mississippi judge's order against a local newspaper sparks censorship claims
Description: A judge in Mississippi has ordered a small town newspaper to take down an editorial critical of city officials. The paper's owner calls it a violation of free speech.

Title: Germany goes to the polls at a crucial time for the future of Europe-U.S. relations
Description: At a pivotal time for Europe and NATO, Germany holds elections on Sunday. NPR's Scott Simon speaks to Constanze Stelzenmüller of the Brookings Institution about the stakes of the election.

Title: Trump shakes up Pentagon leadership, fires the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
Description: We look at Friday night's shakeup at the Pentagon, with the announcement of more staff cuts and a change in a top leadership position.

Title: Foreign policy experts struggle to predict Trump's next move with Russia
Description: President Trump upended U.S. - Russia policy in one week, and foreign policy experts are trying to understand why and what might come next.

Title: Days into prison guard strike at NY state prisons, inmates say they feel unsafe
Description: This week New York State prisons saw strikes, prison unrest and correctional officer charges in the beating death of an inmate.

Title: Trump order shrinks the trust that manages San Francisco's iconic Presidio Park
Description: In an executive order this week, President Trump called to shrink the trust that manages the iconic park known as Presidio in San Francisco.

Title: Trump administration plans mass firing at office that funds homelessness programs
Description: Staffing at the HUD office that pays for housing and support services across the country is slated to be cut by 84%. Advocates warn such heavy cuts could make record-high homelessness even worse. (Image credit: Jeff Chiu)

Title: How many fourth-graders does it take to make a podcast? Here's what we learned
Description: Students in an elementary school broadcasting club in California are among the youngest winners of NPR's Student Podcast Challenge. (Image credit: Alan Nakkash for NPR)

Title: Here's what to know about Germany's election this Sunday
Description: An economic slump, an immigration crisis and the lifting of a security blanket provided for decades by the U.S. are issues on the minds of German voters. The far-right AfD is polling in second place. (Image credit: VOLKER HARTMANN)

Title: Hamas releases Israeli hostages, returns remains of Shiri Bibas
Description: Hamas to release the last six live hostages whose freedom they agreed to under the current ceasefire deal. (Image credit: Omar Al-Qattaa)

Title: Arab leaders huddle in Saudi Arabia in pushback to Trump's Gaza plans
Description: Leaders from Egypt, Jordan and other Arab states met in Saudi Arabia to discuss alternative plans for Gaza's future than the one laid out by President Trump, which calls for displacing Palestinians. (Image credit: Saudi Royal Palace)

Title: Federal prisons prep to move trans inmates as early as next week
Description: The Bureau of Prisons is moving forward with plans to move transgender inmates out of prisons that align with their gender identity and into facilities that align with their assigned sex at birth. (Image credit: Mark Lennihan)

Title: Trump fires the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
Description: Trump announced the dismissal of Air Force Gen. Charles Q. Brown Jr. and said he would nominate Lt. Gen. Dan Caine, a retired three-star general, to succeed him as the top U.S. military officer. (Image credit: Alex Wong)

Title: Judge largely blocks Trump's executive orders ending federal support for DEI programs
Description: A U.S. district judge granted a preliminary injunction blocking the administration from terminating or changing federal contracts they consider equity-related. (Image credit: Ben Curtis)

Title: NBC settles defamation lawsuit with doctor falsely labeled 'uterus collector'
Description: MSNBC had aired stories falsely claiming the doctor performed mass hysterectomies on female detainees at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Georgia. (Image credit: Colin Young-Wolff/Colin Young-Wolff/Invision/AP)

Title: Federal judge hears arguments to decide the future of Trump's federal funding freeze
Description: The case, brought by attorneys general in 22 states and the District of Columbia, represents a pivotal test for the administration as it pursues a dramatic review of government spending priorities. (Image credit: Ben Curtis)

Title: A brief history of beards and baseball after the Yankees lift their no beard policy
Description: The New York Yankees are changing a nearly 50-year-old policy that banned beards. Here are some things to know about the history of beards in major league baseball. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Man who stabbed Salman Rushdie convicted of attempted murder
Description: Hadi Matar faces up to 25 years in prison for the attack that left the 77-year-old writer blind in one eye. (Image credit: Tobias Schwarz)

Title: Luigi Mangione's lawyer claims he was searched illegally during arrest
Description: Luigi Mangione, who is accused of killing UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, had his first court appearance since he was arraigned in December on charges including murder as an act of terrorism. (Image credit: Curtis Means)

Title: Supreme Court punts on order that blocked Trump's firing of special counsel
Description: Per Congress' directive, the occupant of the position can only be fired for 'inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.' (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Trump's passport policy leaves trans, intersex Americans in the lurch
Description: President Trump's executive order that the federal government recognizes only two sexes, male and female, is disrupting the lives of some trans, nonbinary and intersex people applying for passports. (Image credit: Jenny Kane)

Title: One month in, mixed results in Trump's immigration crackdown
Description: The White House is touting the first month of its immigration crackdown as a big success. But questions remain about the Venezuelan migrants who had been detained at the naval base in Guantánamo Bay.

Title: The latest on the 178 Venezuelan migrants who were being held at Guantanamo Bay
Description: The White House is touting the first month of its immigration crackdown as a big success. But questions remain about the Venezuelan migrants who had been detained at the naval base in Guantánamo Bay.

Title: Two Greenlanders share contrasting views on U.S. overtures to acquire their homeland
Description: Two Greenlanders share contrasting views on U.S. overtures to acquire their homeland, following a January visit to the territory by President Trump's eldest son.

Title: Remembering a Musical Giant in Mexico
Description: We remember Paquita la del Barrio, who sang about romantic heartbreak and the pain of infidelity, spitting out insults with relish, and empowering a whole generation of women. Our correspondent in Mexico explains what she meant to her fans.

Title: As Trump works more closely with Russia, Ukraine is left in a bind
Description: President Trump is diverging from decades of U.S. foreign policy when it comes to Russia.

Title: The Netherlands will return more than 100 bronze artifacts to Nigeria
Description: The artifacts were stolen by British soldiers in the late 19th century and eventually made their way to a Dutch collection. (Image credit: Freek van den Bergh)

Title: What happens if the Education Department is abolished?
Description: The Department of Education is a big con job.' That's just one of the things President Trump has said about one of the most high profile departments in federal government — a department Trump says he wants to eliminate.Trump says he wants to save money, and kill policies he doesn't like. Trump and Elon Musk's DOGE has already started cutting funding from the department. The Trump administration wants the Department of Education gone. But can they get rid of it, and what could be lost in the process? For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.Email us at considerthis@npr.org. (Image credi...

Title: Federal judge wants 'adversarial' review of NYC Mayor Eric Adams-DOJ deal
Description: Corruption charges against New York City Mayor Eric Adams are on hold while a judge seeks legal input on whether the DOJ can dismiss them. (Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

Title: After mass layoffs, some federal agencies are trying to bring employees back
Description: A number of federal agencies, from HHS to the USDA, have laid off employees only to rescind those terminations days later. An expert says it 'suggests something about mismanagement of government.' (Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein)

Title: Can there be peace in Ukraine, or is Putin just playing for time?
Description: As the Trump administration works toward a halt in the fighting, many experts fear that Ukraine will be forced to accept a ceasefire deal that will only give Russian forces a badly needed breather. (Image credit: Evelyn Hockstein)

Title: Israel says body returned by Hamas not that of hostage
Description: Israel identified the remains of child hostages but said another body from Hamas was not their mother as claimed. And near Tel Aviv, explosions hit threes buses, but no injuries were reported. (Image credit: Mahmoud Illean)

Title: Israel says returned body isn't a hostage. And, FEMA cuts building code efforts
Description: FEMA has cut employees and is now halting efforts to improve building codes. And, Israel says one of the bodies Hamas returned does not belong to any known hostage. (Image credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/AFP)

Title: What to know about the case against former Spanish soccer head Luis Rubiales
Description: The former president of Spain's soccer federation was found guilty of sexual assault for kissing player Jenni Hermoso after the 2023 women's World Cup. Here's what to know about the case. (Image credit: Chema Moya)

Title: What even IS art? The quiz doesn't know — but do you?
Description: Plus: Why are there so many 'Bridget Jones' movies? Who all resigned over the Eric Adams drama? And what phrase originated on 'SNL'?

Title: A far-right influencer is getting invitations to travel with Trump Cabinet members
Description: Jack Posobiec, a prominent influencer, has a long history of promoting antisemitic and white supremacist content. He traveled to Ukraine with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent last week. (Image credit: Dominic Gwinn)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: More than 170 migrants held at Guantánamo flown back to Venezuela, no injuries reported after 3 buses explode near Tel Aviv, and the Trump administration fires more than 200 FEMA employees.

Title: Israel IDs child hostage remains but says another body from Hamas was not mother
Description: In a dramatic development in Israel, authorities said after forensic testing that a body returned by Hamas is not who the militants claimed it to be.

Title: No injuries reported after 3 buses explode near Tel Aviv in suspected militant attack
Description: Three buses exploded near Tel Aviv in what authorities suspect is an attack by militants. No injuries were reported.

Title: In U.S. reversal, President Trump attacks Zelenskyy and blames Ukraine for war
Description: President Trump has recently made a series of statements in which he sounds more aligned with Russian President Vladimir Putin than with Ukraine. So what is Trump's ultimate goal?

Title: Latvia 'cannot exist without multilateralism, without democracies,' ex-PM says on U.S. shift
Description: Former Latvian Prime Minister Krisjanis Karins gives a Baltic perspective on the U.S. policy shift on Ukraine. (Image credit: Thierry Monasse)

Title: Former Latvian PM Karinš gives a view from the Baltics of the U.S. U-turn on Ukraine
Description: NPR's Michel Martin asks Krišjanis Karinš, former prime minister of Latvia, about the view from the Baltics of America's U-turn on the war in Ukraine.

Title: When your boss asks you to do something you consider unethical, should you resign?
Description: When is it the right ethical choice to leave a job? NPR's A Martinez speaks with Alex Guerrero, a professor of philosophy at Rutgers University, about moral red lines in the workplace.

Title: Elon Musk's role in government raises conflict-of-interest issues
Description: Elon Musk is working to slash federal spending while also promoting his business ventures. Experts in government ethics are worried he's acting in his own best interest and not in the country's.

Title: Ukrainian journalist Maksym Butkevych describes his experience as soldier and POW
Description: NPR speaks with Ukrainian journalist and activist Maksym Butkevych, who volunteered for the Ukrainian armed forces after Russia's full-scale invasion and became a Russian prisoner of war.

Title: More than 170 migrants held at Guantánamo flown back to Venezuela
Description: Nearly all the migrants held at Guantánamo — 177 Venezuelans — have been flown back to Venezuela. Court records show about one-third had no criminal record, contradicting administration claims.

Title: More than 200 FEMA employees fired, raising concerns among disaster experts
Description: As wildfires and floods happen more often, experts are concerned about the more than 200 layoffs at FEMA. NPR also found that FEMA is backtracking on work to make buildings safer during disasters.

Title: Australia warns airlines to beware of Chinese naval exercises in the Tasman Sea
Description: China had given notice that its warships could potentially fire live weapons during an exercise in the Tasman Sea, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Justice Department broadens Jan. 6 pardons to cover gun, drug-related charges
Description: In a new development, the Department of Justice said Trump's pardon of Jan. 6 defendants should apply more broadly and include separate gun charges, as well. (Image credit: JIM WATSON)

Title: Why are 'fireworks' coming from a black hole? This is what scientists say
Description: A team of astrophysicists have found flares of light in Sagittarius A*, a supermassive black hole in the center of the Milky Way. (Image credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, Ralf Crawford (STScI))

Title: Venezuelan mothers organize on chat group to fight Guantánamo detentions
Description: The mothers met in a Whatsapp group. They have vowed to fight until their sons, who they say have not committed crimes and do not have ties to gangs, are released. (Image credit: Via the Sequera, Roldán, and Arapé families)

Title: Reversing U.S. policy, Trump attacks Zelenskyy, blames Ukraine for war with Russia
Description: The U.S. has been the strongest supporter of Ukraine in its war with Russia. Yet with a series of blunt comments, President Trump now sounds more aligned with Russia than Ukraine. (Image credit: SAUL LOEB)

Title: Greenlandic politician describes struggle to remember 'America has good people'
Description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Greenlandic parliamentary candidate Naaja Nathanielsen about the continued Trump administration push to acquire the territory.

Title: The new head of Syria has governed before. Here's what his leadership looked like
Description: The head of a rebel group is now the head of Syria. How will he lead a country destroyed by civil war and sectarianism? NPR found clues in a region in northern Syria, where he governed for years.

Title: Marco Rubio is absent as ministers from world's richest countries meet in South Africa
Description: Foreign ministers from the world's top economies are meeting for the G20 in South Africa. But the U.S. is conspicuous in its absence.

Title: How Will the New Syria Be Governed?
Description: After 14 years of a devastating civil war, Syria is in the process of reinventing itself. One big question is how the country will be governed now that the more than 50 years of rule by the Assad family has come to an end. For clues on what the future might hold, our correspondent goes to the city that was run by a rebel group during the war. That group led the toppling of the Assad regime and now controls the interim government.

Title: NY Governor won't remove NYC Mayor Adams from office, another win for President Trump
Description: NYC Mayor Eric Adams emerged as a key ally of President Trump on his immigration crackdown after Trump's DOJ agreed to shelve corruption charges. Governor Hochul says Adams will remain in office. (Image credit: Elsa/Getty Images)

Title: Senate confirms Kash Patel, fierce critic of FBI, to head the bureau
Description: Republicans welcomed Kash Patel's confirmation, seeing him as someone who can fix the FBI's alleged targeting of conservatives in recent years. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Everything to know about the MLB's ball-strike challenge system at spring training
Description: This spring, MLB players can challenge ball and strike calls. The camera-based system is only an experiment for now — but it has the baseball world wondering where to draw the line with technology. (Image credit: Phil Long)

Title: Mexico warns the US not to 'invade our sovereignty' in fight against cartels
Description: As the US officially designates six Mexican cartels as terrorist groups, Mexico's president warns the United States against any violation of its territory. (Image credit: Marco Ugarte)

Title: Trump order aims to cut benefits for those without legal status. Most already don't qualify.
Description: A new executive order aims to prevent taxpayer money from supporting people in the U.S. without legal status and targets federal funding for cities and states that support sanctuary policies. (Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)

Title: DOGE saved far less than claimed. And, Trump blames Zelenskyy for Russia's invasion
Description: An online tracker claims DOGE has saved $55 billion in federal spending, but NPR has found this to be false. And, Trump blames the Ukrainian president for Russia's invasion. (Image credit: Jim Watson)

Title: China repatriates more than 1,000 online scam workers rescued from Myanmar
Description: Thailand, China and Myanmar have coordinated efforts over the past month to shut down the scam centers that bilked victims around the world out of billions of dollars. (Image credit: Sarot Meksophawannakul)

Title: A gold-framed Trump mug shot is hanging just outside of the Oval Office
Description: President Trump's mug shot is one of the first things visitors will see when approaching the Oval Office. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: A military vet and a scientist were securing America's food system. Trump fired them
Description: More than 10,000 federal employees who had yet to complete their probationary periods have been fired by the Trump administration, including those who work to protect American agriculture. (Image credit: Alyssa Pointer for NPR)

Title: Black farmers among those left in limbo amid federal funding freeze
Description: The federal government has historically discriminated against Black farmers. The recent funding halt from the Trump administration presents yet another hurdle to those who have spent decades fighting for equity in farming. (Image credit: Dee Dwyer)

Title: African American Read-Ins have become a Black History Month tradition nationwide
Description: Since their founding in 1990, African American Read-Ins have become a Black History Month tradition at school and community gatherings nationwide.

Title: Department of Agriculture employee reacts after he was fired on Presidents Day
Description: The money that the Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE, claims to be saving comes at a huge cost to the workers they're firing. NPR sat down with one federal employee fired on Presidents Day.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: President Trump escalates attacks on Ukrainian President Zelenskyy, NPR analysis shows DOGE savings claims don't add up, and Hamas releases the bodies of four Israeli hostages.

Title: Cost of securing events in New Orleans rises after deadly New Year's Day attack
Description: Carnival season is in full swing in New Orleans. The cost of securing parades has become more expensive for organizers since the deadly New Year's Day attack on Bourbon Street that killed 14 people.

Title: The Damascus neighborhood of Syria's new leader celebrates his new role
Description: The Damascus neighborhood of the man who has been leading Syria's new caretaker government celebrates his new role and reflects on the last 14 years of civil war.

Title: Texans raise hopes and concerns over Elon Musk's growing footprint in the state
Description: For years, Elon Musk has been expanding his business empire in Texas. And that growing footprint is raising hopes and concerns among those who live in his path.

Title: Trump moves to stop congestion pricing tolls in New York City
Description: The Trump administration is putting the brakes on New York City's toll congestion pricing program. The Transportation Department has revoked federal approval of the tolls, which began in January.

Title: Why independent agencies were created to be independent
Description: President Trump claims power over independent regulators in a new order. NPR asks Jane Manners, law professor at Temple University, why independent agencies were created to be independent. (Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)

Title: Why Congress shields some agencies from presidential control
Description: President Trump has claimed power over independent regulators in a new order. NPR asks Jane Manners, law professor at Temple University, why Congress shields some agencies from presidential control.

Title: As LA recovers from wildfires, debate resurfaces over how to build in high-risk areas
Description: As Los Angeles begins a slow recovery from destructive and deadly wildfires, local planners are trying to strike a balance between expediting rebuilding and public safety.

Title: Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh feeling the impact of U.S. international aid cuts
Description: President Trump's decisions have already started to impact many people around the world who depend on U.S. humanitarian assistance, including the Rohingya refugees living in Bangladesh.

Title: Trump escalates attacks on Zelenskyy while falsely blaming him for Russia's invasion
Description: President Trump is escalating his personal attacks on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, calling him a 'dictator.' It's the latest example in the explosive relationship between the two leaders.

Title: Federal judge says he will decide soon on charges against NYC Mayor Eric Adams
Description: Federal judge Dale Ho says he'll soon decide whether federal corruption and bribery charges against New York City Mayor Eric Adams should stand or be dismissed.

Title: Hamas releases the bodies of four Israeli hostages, including mother and young sons
Description: Today's release is the first time Hamas has handed over the bodies of hostages during the war, although several have been recovered by Israeli forces in Gaza and returned to Israel. (Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)

Title: The Evolution of Presidential Power
Description: What can and can't the president do — and how do we know? The framers of the U.S. Constitution left the powers of the executive branch powers deliberately vague, and in doing so opened the door for every president to decide how much power they could claim. Over time, that's become quite a lot. This episode originally ran in 2020 and has been updated with new material.To access bonus episodes and listen to Throughline sponsor-free, subscribe to Throughline+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org/throughline.

Title: Panama sends 97 U.S. deportees to migrant camp after they refused to be repatriated
Description: The migrants refused to be repatriated to their countries. They will be held in a migration facility near the Darien Gap along the Colombian border until third countries can be found to take them. (Image credit: Agustin Herrera)

Title: Hegseth directs Pentagon to find $50 billion in cuts this year
Description: The cuts would be as drastic as sequestration in 2013, the law passed by Congress that forced the armed services to cut $56 billion in a matter of months. (Image credit: Virginia Mayo)

Title: Military doctors prepare to deploy to Guantanamo for extended stay
Description: Orders to deploy medical personnel suggest the Trump administration is contemplating an extended stay for people at the U.S. base in Cuba.

Title: Judge deliberates after Justice Department pushes to end corruption case against NYC Mayor Adams
Description: During a hearing on Wednesday, Judge Dale Ho questioned federal prosecutors over their decision to suspend criminal charges against Mayor Eric Adams. Judge Ho's ruling is expected soon. (Image credit: Yuki Iwamura)

Title: GOP senators fact check Trump's Ukraine rhetoric, while still backing his strategy
Description: Lawmakers sought to dispel Kremlin talking points echoed by the president that Ukraine was responsible for the war with Russia. But they said Trump should be given room to negotiate. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: Ireland could ban trade with Israeli settlements in Occupied Palestinian Territories
Description: Ireland is poised to pass a BDS bill that would criminalize trade with Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territories and potentially clash with EU trade law.

Title: Is the U.S. headed for autocracy?
Description: Is the United States headed toward autocracy?That's a question prompted by a steady stream of executive orders seeking to consolidate power in the White House and upend long held policies and norms.New York Times Opinion writer M. Gessen lived through much of Russia's slide into autocracy, and wrote a book about it. They argue that one of the ways Vladimir Putin consolidated power... was by making a series of arguments that seemed outrageous at the time — like the idea that the LGBT population was a threat to Russian sovereignty. President Donald Trump's second term has been marked by a string of policy proposals that would have been unthinkable in any other administration.Even if they don't go anywhere, they're reshaping the boundaries of our democr...

Title: Judge weighs DOJ request to drop criminal charges against NYC Mayor Eric Adams
Description: New York City Mayor Eric Adams and DOJ attorneys appeared before federal Judge Dale Ho Tuesday afternoon, arguing that five federal corruption and bribery charges against Adams should be put on hold.

Title: Seven Chilean men are charged with stealing millions from high-profile athletes' homes
Description: Seven Chilean men face federal charges related to a string of burglaries at the homes of six high-profile athletes. NFL quarterbacks Pat Mahomes and Joe Burrows were among the targets. (Image credit: Justice Department)

Title: Chilean crime ring charged in robberies at homes of high-profile athletes
Description: Robberies at a string of NFL and NBA athletes homes have generated headlines lately. Now, The FBI says these are connected to an international crime ring.

Title: Europe's Biggest Economy is in Trouble
Description: Germany's economy boomed as the world underwent globalization. But since then, too little investment, too much bureaucracy and a nearby war in Ukraine has cause Europe's largest economy to stagnate. Title: U.S. foreign aid freeze shuts down critical infrastructure projects in the West Bank
